The king of Saudi Arabia is old and would probably have Salman, Jubeir, or another party broker this meeting if it were going to take place.   Why would such a meeting take place and who would broker such a meeting?  The meeting would take place to reduce regional hostilities between the two rivals--Saudi and Iran.  So who has interest in reducing the hostilities between the two nations?  My best guess is Pakistan would want to reduce tensions but reasons below on why I think this meeting is unlikely.  I'll revise my initial estimate as evidence becomes available. From the Saudi side, Prince Salman is the heir apparent and a likely guy to be asked to arrange such a meeting. However, Salman is the Minister of Defense and that the Saudi Ministry of Defense is accused by Iran of deliberately accused of bombing the Iranian Embassy in Yemen:
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35251917
So it's unlikely Salman would broker such a meeting.  Adel al-Jubeir might broker such a meeting but doesn't seem bent on reducing tensions:

Saudi has become the new 'Great Satan' in Iran, displacing the US

Iran and Saudi Arabia have always had and will continue to have overlapping interests with respect to a number of issues but that more or less becomes irrelevant when the enmity between two countries runs this deep.
Rouhani's government has tried to reach out to the Saudis in many ways, both publicly and behind the scenes, but there have been very few public, high-level meetings and there would have be plenty of buildup (many off-the-record meetings at lower levels, then perhaps some influential statesmen meeting behind scenes, then low-level diplomats/oil experts, then higher level diplomats and so on) before Rouhani and Salman would ever dream of meeting each other. If this were to ever happen, it would takes years to arrive at.
The key problem here will continue be the perception that the ME must go this way or that...that is, the ME must be remade through the Iranian or Saudi perspective. Key players on both sides, particularly the Saudis, perceive the relationship between the countries as a zero-sum game;  a mentality which precludes mutual benefit through cooperation.

Accepting the "but" is a sign the listener has placed the communicative burden of the speaker upon themselves. Transferring this burden from the speaker to the listener unavoidably carries risk. Hassan Rouhani became President of Iran in 2013, and Salman bin Adjulaziz Al Saud gained the throne this year.  Both are relatively new to their respective offices. I am marking this as a relatively low probability for the following reasons: 1) The Saudis have been instrumental in the present low price of oil.  Along with sanctions by other Western governments, this has hurt the Iranian economy, and the Iranian's understand this probably wasn't a mere business decision. 2) The Iranians have an active nuclear weapons program.  _If_ they get a nuclear weapon, the Saudis fear there will be no stopping Iranian aspirations in the Middle East.  Because of the Saudis relationship to and financing of the Pakistani nuclear program, they will probably acquire their own nuclear weapons shortly after a successful Iranian test.  There were reports that the Saudis told the Obama Administration that Iran's nuclear installations should be immediately attacked.  Obviously, this didn't happen.  But if _I_ could find articles about it, so could the Iranian intelligence service. 3) Both governments are concerned with ISIS.  While a relatively small thing now, it has the potential to become a Very Big Thing quickly.  The Saudis are building a 600 mile fence to keep ISIS out of the Kingdom.  OTOH, would anyone be particularly surprised if there were a deal between ISIS and Iran to divide Iraq between themselves?  There have been complaints (for years) that Iran has actively engaged, and through proxies, to destabilize Iraq.  BTW, where is the Mahdi Army in all the action? 4) The on-going conflict in Yemen is a fight between an Iranian proxy and Saudi Arabia.  The Saudis may have to treat with Iran to disengage, but it is too early for that. 5) History is against a meeting, because there is long standing bad feelings between these two countries.  Here's an interesting article about recent history (especially if you like spy stories): http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/136917/matthew-kroenig/time-to-attack-iran "In early October, U.S. officials accused Iranian operatives of planning to assassinate Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States on American soil. Iran denied the charges, but the episode has already managed to increase tensions between Washington and Tehran. Although the Obama administration has not publicly threatened to retaliate with military force, the allegations have underscored the real and growing risk that the two sides could go to war sometime soon -- particularly over Iran’s advancing nuclear program." Reasons why a meeting could take place. 1) Russia has entered the Middle East to defend its interests in Syria.  They are filling a void left by the United States.  Saudi Arabia may try to negotiate deals separately from the US. 2) The Saudis may need to buy time to get their own nuclear weapon.  Engaging with Iran could buy that time.

An increased amount of anti-Saudi agitation has been evident from the Iranian regime, and from high levels of it at that, in recent weeks.  Of course, there may be elements of geopolitical bluster involved here - but some willingness to work together on areas of common concern but differing interests (e.g. the conflicts in Syria and/or Yemen) would be needed for such a meeting of such high-level officials to occur. Some observations:
Iran's re-entry into the world oil market complicates things for Saudi Arabia Both are members of OPEC but, until now, SA has been calling the shots on production quotas. 
Iran's infrastructure is decayed, increasing its lifting costs. SA has very low lifting costs and a modern infrastructure. SA fights these production wars by flooding the market until the other guy goes broke. They might win such a contest with Iran. SA has more or less broken Venezuela that way.
Iran's primary source of hard currency is oil. After sanctions are lifted, several western nations will want to increase trade with Iran, so they will also want Iran to have a source of hard currency. This makes them economic allies of Iran against SA. 
Russia has its own oil issues, but China is in a position to make rapid improvements in Iranian fields in return for status as a long-term preferred buyer. 
Rouhani has spent a lot of political capital on the P5+1 nuclear deal. Hardliners likely won't want him talking to ideological opponent like SA and he may not have enough political capital left to do it anyway.
Hardliners might be more receptive to foreign direct investment, say from China, than to production quota negotiations with SA. 
I wonder if this could mean the beginning of the end of OPEC?
